Response.BaseQuestion: What is a clinical study?
Response.Content: Clinical research studies are often conducted by means of a clinical study. The United States National Institutes of Health defines a clinical study as "one type of clinical research that follows a pre-defined plan or protocol." A clinical study is a scientifically controlled study of the safety and effectiveness of investigational drugs and devices for various diseases and conditions. These studies determine if these investigational drugs or devices are safe to use and will improve the health of people. Before a medication, therapy, or medical device can be made available to the general public, it has to go through several phases of clinical research.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are the phases of a clinical trial?
What are the types of clinical trials?
What is a clinical trial protocol?
What is being tested in this study?/What is the purpose of this study?

Response.BaseQuestion: What agency regulates clinical trials?
Response.Content: Clinical studies in the United States are regulated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, often referred to as the FDA.The FDA is responsible for protecting and promoting public health through the regulation and supervision of medications, foods, medical devices, and other products. One role of the FDA is to ensure adherence to laws that are consistent with principles known as good clinical practices, or GCPs.These principles are designed to enhance the quality of clinical study data, as well as to ensure the protection of study participants like you.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is a Data Safety and Monitoring Committee?
What is an Institutional Review Board (IRB)?
If I participate in this study, will I be told what other options I have?
What is informed consent?
Will my name be publically used during the study or when the results are published?

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the phases of a clinical trial?
Response.Content: Clinical studies are typically performed in "phases." These phases are designed to build evidence that an investigational drug or device will be beneficial to patients with a particular disease or condition. Before a medication can be tested in human subjects, pre-clinical testing occurs in a lab environment that may involve animals. The goal is to gather data on whether the investigational drug or device has the potential to work in treating the disease.Before a medication moves to testing in humans, the Food and Drug Administration, or FDA, reviews pre-clinical testing results to determine if the investigational compound can further be studied in humans. If the investigational compound can be studied in humans, that research is divided into different phases. In Phase I, researchers test an investigational medication in a small group of people to evaluate its safety and identify side effects. Often, healthy volunteers are used as participants.In Phase II, the investigational medication is given to a larger group of people to see if it is effective, determine optimal dosage, and to further evaluate safety.In Phase III, the investigational medication is given to a large group of people to confirm effectiveness, monitor side effects, and compare it to existing treatments.In Phase IV studies, the medication is further studied after it has been approved for sale by relevant regulatory authorities. Further information is gathered on the medication's effect on different populations and its long-term side effects.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is a clinical study?
What are the types of clinical trials?
What is a clinical trial protocol?
Has the study investigational medication ever been tested before?
What is being tested in this study?/What is the purpose of this study?

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the types of clinical trials?
Response.Content: There are two main types of clinical studies: Placebo-controlled and head-to-head studies. A placebo-controlled study means that one group of patients will receive the investigational drug to be evaluated, while a second group, often known as the control group, will receive a placebo. This placebo often looks just like the experimental drug but is designed to have no effect on patients.Placebos are often used in blinded studies, which are studies where the patients do not know whether the are receiving the experimental drug or placebo. Blinding is used to help eliminate the "placebo effect," which is bias introduced into the study. Bias may result from a patient's belief that he or she is receiving a certain treatment or the researcher's belief that a certain result will occur.In a head-to-head or comparative effectiveness study, one group of patients receives the investigational drug to be evaluated, while a second group of patients receives a different therapy. This allows researchers to see how the experimental treatment performs in comparison to other therapies. In a head-to-head study there is no placebo, and the patient has a chance of receiving either the investigational drug or another treatment. In most cases, the other treatment, also called a comparator or reference treatment is already commonly prescribed by doctors for patients with the disease that is being investigated in the study. The reference treatment is often referred to as the "standard of care."

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is a clinical study?
What are the phases of a clinical trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a Data Safety and Monitoring Committee?
Response.Content: A Data Safety and Monitoring Committee, sometimes known as a Data and Safety Monitoring Board, is an independent group of experts who monitor patient safety and treatment effectiveness data during the course of a clinical study.This group typically includes 3 to 10 members and is authorized to recommend that a study be stopped due to safety concerns. This may occur after the group reviews a subset of the data from the study that shows the study treatment is not effective or if the investigational treatment is so beneficial that it should urgently be considered for approval by the regulatory authorities.Members of the Data Safety and Monitoring Committee are independent from anyone involved in the study.The committee is usually made up of expert clinicians with knowledge of the disease or condition being treated, statisticians, and sometimes a patient advocacy representative.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is an Institutional Review Board (IRB)?
Response.Content: An Institutional Review Board, or Ethical Review Board, is a committee charged with approving, monitoring, and reviewing clinical research involving humans.The main goal of the committee is to make sure the study is ethical and the rights and welfare of participants are protected. Among other things, this includes making sure that research risks are minimized and are reasonable in relation to any potential benefits.Prior to the start of the clinical study, this committee will conduct a risk-benefit analysis to determine whether the research should be performed.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What agency regulates clinical trials?

What information will the study doctor be able to share with me?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a clinical trial protocol?
Response.Content: A protocol is a written document detailing the study research plan. A clinical study protocol is designed to answer specific research questions, as well as safeguard the health of participants. In general, a protocol describes an overview of the study's objectives; what types of people may participate; the number of participants needed for the studies; the schedule of tests, procedures, medications, and dosages; the length of the studies; and what information will be gathered about participants.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is a clinical study?
What are the phases of a clinical trial?
Can I get a copy of the study protocol?
Who can participate in this study?
Why might I be excluded from the study?

Response.BaseQuestion: How are my rights protected while participating in a study?
Response.Content: In order to conduct a clinical study, the research team must agree to comply with ethical guidelines and laws designed to protect patient volunteers, as well as to preserve the integrity of the research. One of the main points of the ethical guidelines is that individuals should be treated with respect from the time they are approached for possible participation in the study, throughout their participation, and after their participation ends. This includes, but is not limited to, your right to privacy and respecting your right to change your mind about being in the study at any point.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is a Data Safety and Monitoring Committee?
What is an Institutional Review Board (IRB)?

What information will the study doctor be able to share with me?

What rights do I have if I participate in a clinical study?/Can I quit the clinical study at any time?/Will the risks/side effects be explained to me?

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I be sure that the study tests are appropriate?
Response.Content: The nature of participating in a clinical study means that you may receive an investigational drug or device. However, all procedures and tests performed prior to, during, and after participation ends are clearly outlined in the clinical study protocol and are subject to ethical guidelines and laws. These procedures and guidelines are applied to all participants in the study. This includes, but is not limited to, your right to privacy and respecting your right to change your mind about being in the study at any point.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is an Institutional Review Board (IRB)?
How are my rights protected while participating in a study?
Will I be able to talk to the study doctors during the study?
Is it normal to feel uncertain about participating in a study?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a placebo?/When is a placebo used?/Are placebos ethical?
Response.Content: Patients participating in a placebo-controlled clinical study are told during the informed consent process that there is a chance that they could receive the investigational drug or device or an inactive substance, also called placebo, while participating in the study. A placebo often looks like the investigational medication, but it has no active ingredient in it.Placebos are used in clinical research to help evaluate the safety and effectiveness of an investigational medication.However, in some studies, such as head-to-head comparative studies, a placebo is not used, and a patient has a chance of receiving the investigational drug or another treatment.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Is there a placebo in this study?
What will the study treatment entail?

Response.BaseQuestion: What information will the study doctor be able to share with me?
Response.Content: Under the terms of the ethical guidelines and laws that govern clinical studies, all researchers must inform participants of the potential risks, benefits, and available alternatives associated with participation in a clinical study. However, it should be noted that in blinded studies, researchers will not be able to tell you which study treatment you are receiving because they need to preserve the scientific integrity of the study. However, this information is available in case of emergency.

Response.BaseQuestion: If I participate in this study, will I be told what other options I have?
Response.Content: When you sign up to participate in a clinical study, the researchers must inform you of the available alternatives to joining the clinical study. Under the terms of the ethical guidelines that govern clinical studies if you join a study, , the research team must inform you of new information that might emerge over the course of the research, particularly data that might change their assessment of the risks and benefits of participating in the clinical study.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is meant by standard of care treatment?
Response.Content: In a clinical study, the standard of care treatment refers to any therapy that is accepted by medical professionals as an approved treatment for a certain type of disease and one that is typically used by health care professionals. Standard of care treatment can also be known as best practice, standard medical care, or standard of care.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are the types of clinical trials?
What are the benefits of participating in a clinical study?
Is there a placebo in this study?
Why is the study treatment switched for participants during the study?
How do the tests compare to the standard tests for my condition?

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the benefits of participating in a clinical study?
Response.Content: There is no guarantee that you will benefit in any way. Although there are precautions in place to protect participants, your condition or health could remain the same, improve, or get worse. Participating in a study may help researchers learn more about your disease or condition and may help in the development of improved treatments that may benefit others with your condition in the future.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is meant by standard of care treatment?
What if the study treatment does not work?
Should I talk to my regular doctor about this study?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is randomization?/Why is a study randomized?
Response.Content: Randomization in a clinical study is when participants are assigned to a particular group and the different groups receive different study treatments. Clinical studies are randomized so that the researchers can compare the safety and effectiveness of different study treatments. Sometimes, investigational medications are compared to a placebo, which looks like the investigational medication but contains no active ingredients.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are the types of clinical trials?
Is there a placebo in this study?
What will the study treatment entail?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is informed consent?
Response.Content: Laws and ethical guidelines governing clinical research in many countries around the world require that potential study participants be given certain information about the planned study through a process known as "informed consent." This process is designed to accurately inform individuals of the purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to the clinical study. The informed consent process also ensures that participants understand information about the study and how it relates to their own health or interests. It also provides an opportunity for an individual to make a voluntary decision about whether to participate in the study. Once you have had enough time to read and understand the informed consent form and had time to discuss it with the study doctor, you can determine if you wish to participate in the study. If you choose to participate, you will sign the informed consent form. Even if you sign the form, you can still withdraw from the study at any time, for any reason.

Response.BaseQuestion: What if I do not understand the Informed Consent form? Who can help me understand the Informed Consent form?
Response.Content: The consent form may contain words that you or your loved ones do not understand. Please ask the study doctor or other members of the clinical research team to explain any words or information that you do not clearly understand. Before you make a decision to participate in the study, it is important that you understand the information in this form. You should not sign this form if you have any questions that have not been fully answered by the study staff or if you are not comfortable with the answers.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is informed consent?
Can I get a second opinion before I decide to participate?
Who can help me decide what is best for me?
What is the informed consent form?

Response.BaseQuestion: What rights do I have if I participate in a clinical study?/Can I quit the clinical study at any time?/Will the risks/side effects be explained to me?
Response.Content: Taking part in a clinical study is your decision, and you keep all of your rights. For example, you are to be given enough time to decide whether to participate and to make that decision without any pressure from the people who are doing the clinical research. You can also refuse to participate in the study or stop participating at any time. Your decision not to participate will not affect your right to your usual care that is unrelated to the research study. In addition, you have the right to be told why the clinical study is being done, what will happen, and what you will be asked to do if you are in the study. You will also be informed of any reasonably foreseeable risks, discomforts, or side effects that may occur during the study and who will pay for any treatment related to the clinical research. You have the right to have your questions answered by the clinical research team at any time and receive a copy of your signed informed consent form.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is an Institutional Review Board (IRB)?
How are my rights protected while participating in a study?

Can I get a second opinion before I decide to participate?
How long do I have to make my decision?

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I get a second opinion before I decide to participate?
Response.Content: You are free to get as many opinions as you feel you need before you decide to participate in a clinical study. A second-opinion can help you better understand the existing treatments available to you and help you determine if participation in the study is a good option for you both personally and medically.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What if I do not understand the Informed Consent form? Who can help me understand the Informed Consent form?

If I say no to a trial now, can I change my mind later?
How long do I have to make my decision?
Should I talk to my regular doctor about this study?

Response.BaseQuestion: If I say no to a trial now, can I change my mind later?
Response.Content: If you decline to participate in a clinical study, you can change your mind later as long as the study is still accepting new patients. During the informed consent process, it is recommended that you discuss any concerns that you may have about the study with the clinical research team. You should also ask how long they plan to enroll study participants and if there will be an additional enrollment period at a later date. At no point should you feel pressured by the clinical research team to join the study. It should also be noted that if you enroll in the study and decide that you no longer wish to participate, you can withdraw at any time without penalty.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will there be other opportunities to participate in a clinical trial?/Where can I find out about studies for my condition?
Response.Content: It is difficult to say whether there will be other opportunities to participate in future clinical studies. Although new investigational drugs and devices are constantly moving through the clinical research process, there is no guarantee that you will be a good candidate for these studies. Clinical trials for many conditions are listed on ClinicalTrials.gov, a website sponsored by the U.S. National Institutes of Health.

RQ.BaseQuestion: If I say no to a trial now, can I change my mind later?
How long do I have to make my decision?
What will be the impact on the study if I decide not to participate? Will the study staff still proceed if I decide not to enroll?

Response.BaseQuestion: How long do I have to make my decision?
Response.Content: When you meet with your clinical research team, ask them how long you have to make a decision on whether or not to participate in the clinical study. In general, you can decide to participate at any time during the enrollment period, which for some studies is only a few months, but for others, can be years. At no point should you feel pressured by the research team to join the study.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Can I get a second opinion before I decide to participate?
If I say no to a trial now, can I change my mind later?
Will there be other opportunities to participate in a clinical trial?/Where can I find out about studies for my condition?

Why might I be excluded from the study?

Response.BaseQuestion: What will be the impact on the study if I decide not to participate? Will the study staff still proceed if I decide not to enroll?
Response.Content: If you choose not to participate in the study, the study will still continue as planned.

RQ.BaseQuestion: If I say no to a trial now, can I change my mind later?
Will there be other opportunities to participate in a clinical trial?/Where can I find out about studies for my condition?
How long do I have to make my decision?
Can I withdraw from the study?

Response.BaseQuestion: Do my family/friends need to know that I am participating in a clinical study?
Response.Content: If you choose to participate in a clinical study, it is up to you if you would like to let your family and friends know of your decision. It can often be helpful to inform family or friends if you will need assistance during the study, such as obtaining transportation to and from clinical site visits or sticking to the treatment plan outlined in the study. You may wish to discuss this study with your family, friends, or your doctor before making your decision to participate.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Will my employer be told about my participation in this clinical study?
Will my name be publically used during the study or when the results are published?
What is the informed consent form?

Response.BaseQuestion: What are single-blind and double-blind studies?
Response.Content: When discussing clinical studies, you might notice that they can also be referred to as "single-blind" or "double-blind."A single-blind study means that the investigators involved in the studies know whether the patient is getting the investigational drug, but the patient is not aware of what study treatment he or she is getting.In a double-blind study, neither the investigator nor the patient knows who is receiving the investigational drug."Blinding" the studies helps reduce the possibility that any intentional or unintentional biases are introduced into the study.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is blinding?/Why is a study blinded?
Will the study staff know what treatment I'm getting?
Why is there an open-label section after one year?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is blinding?/Why is a study blinded?
Response.Content: Often, clinical studies involve something called blinding, which means that the study participants, doctors, and researchers do not know which study treatment a study participant is receiving and therefore cannot affect the study results by introducing their bias about what study results will show.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are single-blind and double-blind studies?
What are the types of clinical trials?
Why is there an open-label section after one year?
What will the study treatment entail?

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the risks of my participation in a clinical study?
Response.Content: All clinical studies have risks. The risks may include things that could make you sick, make you feel uncomfortable, or harm you. Any known risks will be discussed during the consent process, but there is always a possibility of unknown risks. You might experience negative effects related to the study medication while you are participating in the study. All participants will be monitored carefully by the study team for any negative effects.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are the risks or side effects of this study treatment?
Are there risks and side effects of the study medication?
What should I do if I experience side effects?/What happens if my RA gets worse during study treatment?
Could my rheumatoid arthritis get worse when receiving the study treatment?

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I find clinical trials?
Response.Content: To find Pfizer clinical trials that are seeking participants, please visit http://www.pfizer.com/research/clinical_trials . In addition, clinical trials for many conditions are listed on http://ClinicalTrials.gov , a website sponsored by the U.S. National Institutes of Health.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Introduction to program
Contact information

Response.BaseQuestion: Introduction to program
Response.Content: The goal of this site is to give you more information about what it is like to take part in a clinical trial, which is also known as a research study. This site has also been developed to provide specific information about the REFLECTIONS study for rheumatoid arthritis. I invite you to explore the site. If you have a question, type it into the box below and we will provide the closest available pre-recorded response. Alternatively, we will tell you that we do not have a response to a certain question. This site is not intended to provide medical advice or to replace a conversation with your physician or study doctor. If you have unanswered questions after exploring the site, you should take them to your physician. Questions specific to your diagnosis or other medical advice cannot be provided here.This website is not intended for reporting adverse events or product complaints.If you live in the United States, you may report an adverse event related to Pfizer products by calling 1-800-438-1985. If you prefer, you may contact the U.S. Food and Drug Administration directly. The FDA has established a reporting service known as MedWatch. Through MedWatch health care professionals and consumers can report serious problems they suspect may be associated with the drugs and medical devices they prescribe, dispense, or use. Visit http://www.fda.gov/medwatch or call 1-800-FDA-1088.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is being tested in this study?/What is the purpose of this study?
What will the study treatment entail?

Response.BaseQuestion: Who is managing my study?
Response.Content: The study is managed by a research team that includes doctors, nurses, research assistants, data analysts, and other specialists. The research team often works with other health professionals, including other doctors, nurses, laboratory technicians, and pharmacists to monitor your health during the clinical study.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Will I be able to talk to the study doctors during the study?
Who will be working with me during the clinical study?
Can I use my own doctor/lab/hospital for the tests?
If I get sick during the study, who will be there to help me?
How is my safety checked in this study?

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I get a copy of the study protocol?
Response.Content: You will not be provided with a copy of the protocol. However, the clinical study procedures and requirements will be reviewed with you by study staff prior to your enrollment in the study and will be described in the informed consent form. During this review process, the research team will help to address any questions or concerns you may have about the study design, objective, or what your participation in the study will entail.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is a clinical trial protocol?
What rights do I have if I participate in a clinical study?/Can I quit the clinical study at any time?/Will the risks/side effects be explained to me?
Will I be able to talk to the study doctors during the study?
What is being tested in this study?/What is the purpose of this study?

Response.BaseQuestion: What if the study treatment does not work?
Response.Content: Under the terms of the informed consent process, you will be informed about the risks and benefits of participating in this clinical study. One of the risks associated with participation is that the experimental drug or device may have no therapeutic benefit. However, if you decide that the research does not match your interests or if you simply change your mind, you can withdraw from the clinical study at any time without penalty.

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I change study sites if I move?
Response.Content: If you move over the course of the study and a different study site is closer to your new home, you may have the option of switching to a closer study site. However, in some cases, there may not be a study site close to your new home, which could affect your continued participation in the clinical study. Please let the study staff know if you have any immediate plans to move so they can ensure that you can attend site visits over the course of the study.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Will i have to go to a different doctor for my study?
If I travel a lot, can I still participate?

Response.BaseQuestion: Will i have to go to a different doctor for my study?
Response.Content: Over the course of the clinical study, you will be seen by a research team that includes doctors, nurses, research assistants, data analysts, and other specialists. However, this research team will only provide study-related treatments or procedures, so it's important that you keep seeing your current doctor for regular checkups and other care while you participate in the study. You should tell your regular doctor that you are participating in a clinical study, and you should tell the study doctor if you start taking any new medications not associated with the clinical study.

Response.BaseQuestion: Does my regular doctor know about this study?
Response.Content: Often, your doctor will be the one to tell you about a clinical study. However, in some cases, your doctor may not know about the study that you are considering.

Response.BaseQuestion: Should I talk to my regular doctor about this study?
Response.Content: It is recommended that you let your regular doctor know about your decision to participate in a clinical study. Your doctor knows your health history, which makes him or her a good resource to discuss whether participating in a clinical study might be right for you. In addition, your participation in a clinical study may mean that you will take a different medication or undergo testing that may alter the way in which he or she approaches your treatment.

Response.BaseQuestion: Who can help me decide what is best for me?
Response.Content: Learning all you can about clinical studies can help you decide whether to take part in one. In order to gather information about a clinical study you are considering, you should review the key points of the study with the study doctor. You should actively participate in the informed consent process, ask questions of the study doctor and other research staff, and discuss the clinical study with your doctor if desired. Ultimately, however, it is up to you to decide whether participation in the clinical study is right for you.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will my employer be told about my participation in this clinical study?
Response.Content: If you choose to participate in the study, you are not required to tell your employer. However, it may be wise to inform your boss or manager if participating in the study will interfere with your ability to do your job; for example, if study appointments will require you to take time off of work.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will my name be publically used during the study or when the results are published?
Response.Content: Any data collected about you as part of a clinical study is subject to privacy requirements. The informed consent form will describe how information may be used or disclosed by groups for research purposes. The research team can publish, present, or otherwise disclose data from the study for research purposes; however, your name will not be included in such publications, public presentations, or disclosures.

Response.BaseQuestion: When will I find out about the trial results?
Response.Content: Although study participation is expected to last for a maximum of 2 years, it may take several months or even years after your participation ends for the research team to analyze the data collected and report the results. During the study, you will not have the right to know any information about ongoing study results.

Response.BaseQuestion: Would I have to pay for study medication and tests?
Response.Content: Study participants will not have to pay for the investigational medication, study visits, or study procedures required for the study. The study sponsor will pay for these and any costs associated with the study. However, the sponsor will not cover care or treatment that is not part of the study. You, your insurance company, or your health care provider may need to cover the costs for specific procedures or tests that you would receive even if you were not participating in the study.If you have any questions or concerns related to cost, please ask the study doctor.

Response.BaseQuestion: What will my health insurance cover?
Response.Content: Some insurance plans will not pay for services for people taking part in research studies. Please check with your insurance company to find out what your plan will pay for. Charges for some or all standard of care services may be billed in the usual manner to you or your insurance company. Examinations, scans, laboratory tests, and other medical procedures and treatments that would routinely be needed to monitor and treat your rheumatoid arthritis are known as standard of care services.

Response.BaseQuestion: Who can participate in this study?
Response.Content: You may be able to participate in the study if you are 18 years old or older, have been diagnosed with moderately to severely active rheumatoid arthritis and have taken methotrexate to treat your RA. There are other specific criteria that you doctor will discuss with you.

Response.BaseQuestion: Do I have to do everything the doctor says?
Response.Content: If you decide to participate in the clinical study, you are agreeing to follow the instructions given to you by the study doctor and the rest of the research team. If you have any concerns about your ability to follow the instructions outlined in the study, please speak with the study doctor.

Response.BaseQuestion: What will happen if I miss some study treatment doses or study appointments?
Response.Content: If you miss an appointment, call the study doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. If you are unable to make several study appointments, you may be asked to leave the study and will no longer receive any study treatment.

Response.BaseQuestion: What will happen if I miss some appointments?
Response.Content: When you sign up to participate in this clinical study, you are expected to attend each of the study appointments. The study team will schedule appointments for you in advance. If you expect to miss an appointment, contact the study team immediately to reschedule. If you anticipate that it will be difficult for you to attend any of the planned study visits, please let the research team know as soon as possible so that they can discuss your continued eligibility and enrollment in the study.

Response.BaseQuestion: What happens after I stop or complete my study treatment in the study?
Response.Content: You will have tests and procedures at an end-of-treatment visit once you have received the last dose of the investigational medication or if you must stop taking the investigational medication for any reason. You will also have more tests and procedures at a follow-up visit six weeks after you receive the last dose of the investigational medication. Finally, you will have a phone call with the study site 16 weeks after taking the last dose of the investigational medication.

Response.BaseQuestion: If I travel a lot, can I still participate?
Response.Content: If you travel extensively, you may still be able to participate in the study. Whenever possible, the study team will attempt to make accommodations for your study visits. Before agreeing to take part in this study, please inform the study doctor if you plan to be out of the country or are otherwise unable to undergo testing in connection with the study for a prolonged period of time. The study doctor will need this information to evaluate how your travel may impact your participation and help advise you on whether you would be able to participate in the study at this time. If you have any questions about your particular travel schedule, please contact the study team.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the risks or side effects of this study treatment?
Response.Content: Any known risks will be discussed during the consent process, but there is always a possibility of unknown risks. Like all medications, the investigational medication can cause side effects, although not everybody gets them. Most side effects are mild to moderate. However, some may be serious and require treatment. The informed consent form will tell you more about the risks and known side effects.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is rheumatoid arthritis?
Response.Content: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder that typically affects the small joints in your hands and feet but can also affect other parts of your body. RA is an autoimmune disease, which is when a person's immune system attacks joint tissues and potentially other body parts or organs for unknown reasons.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis?
What causes rheumatoid arthritis?
What are the complications of rheumatoid arthritis?/Does rheumatoid arthritis cause other health problems?
How is rheumatoid arthritis diagnosed?
What treatments exist for rheumatoid arthritis?/What treatments prevent damage to bone and joints caused by rheumatoid arthritis?

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis?
Response.Content: Rheumatoid arthritis causes pain, inflammation, and eventually joint damage and malformation. It can cause people to feel sick, tired, and feverish; it also affects joints symmetrically, so that joint pain is felt on both sides of the body.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is rheumatoid arthritis?
What causes rheumatoid arthritis?
What are the complications of rheumatoid arthritis?/Does rheumatoid arthritis cause other health problems?
How is rheumatoid arthritis diagnosed?
What treatments exist for rheumatoid arthritis?/What treatments prevent damage to bone and joints caused by rheumatoid arthritis?

Response.BaseQuestion: What causes rheumatoid arthritis?
Response.Content: Although it is unclear what causes rheumatoid arthritis, doctors do know that it occurs when the immune system attacks the joints, causing inflammation.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is rheumatoid arthritis?
What are the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis?
What are the complications of rheumatoid arthritis?/Does rheumatoid arthritis cause other health problems?
How is rheumatoid arthritis diagnosed?
What treatments exist for rheumatoid arthritis?/What treatments prevent damage to bone and joints caused by rheumatoid arthritis?

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the complications of rheumatoid arthritis?/Does rheumatoid arthritis cause other health problems?
Response.Content: Rheumatoid arthritis causes pain, inflammation, and eventually joint damage and malformation. It can cause people to feel sick, tired, and feverish; it also affects joints symmetrically, so that joint pain is felt on both sides of the body. RA is also associated with a higher risk of infections; cardiovascular disease, especially ischemic heart disease; and mental health conditions, such as anxiety and depression.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is rheumatoid arthritis?
What are the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis?
What causes rheumatoid arthritis?
How is rheumatoid arthritis diagnosed?
What treatments exist for rheumatoid arthritis?/What treatments prevent damage to bone and joints caused by rheumatoid arthritis?

Response.BaseQuestion: How is rheumatoid arthritis diagnosed?
Response.Content: Rheumatoid arthritis can be difficult to diagnose. Doctors typically check your joints for swelling, redness, and warmth. Blood tests and x-rays may also be used to help doctors diagnose rheumatoid arthritis.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is rheumatoid arthritis?
What are the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis?
What causes rheumatoid arthritis?
What are the complications of rheumatoid arthritis?/Does rheumatoid arthritis cause other health problems?
What treatments exist for rheumatoid arthritis?/What treatments prevent damage to bone and joints caused by rheumatoid arthritis?

Response.BaseQuestion: What treatments exist for rheumatoid arthritis?/What treatments prevent damage to bone and joints caused by rheumatoid arthritis?
Response.Content: There is currently no cure for rheumatoid arthritis; however, medications do exist to help limit pain, increase joint function, and slow down the long-term worsening of the condition. Current treatments for rheumatoid arthritis typically include a combination of medications such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, also called NSAIDs, that reduce pain, swelling, and stiffness, and disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs, also called DMARDs, that help limit the activity of the body's immune system. Aspirin and ibuprofen are examples of commonly used NSAIDs. Methotrexate is an example of a DMARD.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is rheumatoid arthritis?
What are the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis?
What causes rheumatoid arthritis?
What are the complications of rheumatoid arthritis?/Does rheumatoid arthritis cause other health problems?
How is rheumatoid arthritis diagnosed?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is inflammation?
Response.Content: Inflammation is the immune system's response to stimuli, such as pain. The body typically reacts to inflammation through redness, swelling, pain, or a feeling of heat near the affected area.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What causes inflammation?
How is inflammation treated?
What diseases are associated with inflammation?

Response.BaseQuestion: What causes inflammation?
Response.Content: Inflammation often happens when the immune system fights against something that may turn out to be harmful, such as bacteria. In people with rheumatoid arthritis, inflammation occurs when the immune system attacks the joints.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is inflammation?
How is inflammation treated?
What diseases are associated with inflammation?

Response.BaseQuestion: How is inflammation treated?
Response.Content: Current treatments for the inflammation caused by rheumatoid arthritis include a combination of medications. The most common medications used are nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or NSAIDs, like aspirin or ibuprofen. Such medications are meant to reduce pain, swelling, and stiffness.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is inflammation?
What causes inflammation?
What diseases are associated with inflammation?

Response.BaseQuestion: What diseases are associated with inflammation?
Response.Content: Several types of arthritis are associated with inflammation. These types of arthritis include rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, and gouty arthritis.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is inflammation?
What causes inflammation?
How is inflammation treated?

Response.BaseQuestion: What are biosimilars?
Response.Content: Biosimilar medications are highly similar versions of biologic drugs that are already marketed. Examples of marketed biologic drugs include REMICADE, which is manufactured by Janssen Biotech, Inc. and HUMIRA, which is manufactured by AbbVie Inc. Biologic drugs are made from living cells.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is the benefit of biosimilar medications to patients?
Why is Pfizer studying potential biosimilar medications?
What is the difference between biosimilar medications and generic medications?
What is adalimumab?
What is HUMIRA?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the benefit of biosimilar medications to patients?
Response.Content: Biosimilar medications approved for marketing may offer additional options and access to more treatment options for physicians and patients.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are biosimilars?
Why is Pfizer studying potential biosimilar medications?
What is the difference between biosimilar medications and generic medications?
What is adalimumab?
What is HUMIRA?

Response.BaseQuestion: Why is Pfizer studying potential biosimilar medications?
Response.Content: Pfizer is researching potential biosimilar medications so that patients and providers may have additional treatment options for diseases and conditions like rheumatoid arthritis. It is important to develop new medications that are similar to biologic medications because biologic medications have advanced patient care by providing highly effective and targeted treatment options for many diseases and conditions.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is adalimumab?
What is HUMIRA?
What are biosimilars?
What is the benefit of biosimilar medications to patients?
What is the difference between biosimilar medications and generic medications?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the difference between biosimilar medications and generic medications?
Response.Content: Biosimilar medications are highly similar versions of biologic drugs that are already marketed. Biologic drugs are made from living cells. Generic medications, on the other hand, are medications that are identical or bioequivalent to already approved medications. Generic drugs are not made from living cells.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is adalimumab?

Why is Pfizer studying potential biosimilar medications?

Response.Content: To help protect your safety, you will have tests and procedures throughout this study. These include blood tests and an ECG to test your heart.

Response.BaseQuestion: What will I do with my current methotrexate therapy?

Response.BaseQuestion: Will I be able to take other regular medications while participating in this study?
Response.Content: The study treatment will not replace any of your medications; however, the use of some medications is restricted during the study. Your study doctor will ask about the medications you are currently taking and will tell you if any of them cannot be taken during the study. Otherwise, you will continue taking your other usual medications as prescribed by your doctor. If your personal doctor prescribes any other medication while you are in this study, you must first consult the study doctor prior to taking them.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What will I do with my current methotrexate therapy?
Should I continue to see my regular doctor for other medical problems during this study?

Response.BaseQuestion: Is there a placebo in this study?
Response.Content: There is no placebo in this study. The investigational medication is being compared to a currently approved standard of care medication. As a result, all patients will receive the investigational medication or the approved medication. Therefore participants will have an equal or 50 percent chance to be on either one of the assigned treatments.

Response.BaseQuestion: Why is the study treatment switched for participants during the study?
Response.Content: Switching treatment for participants during the study allows participants to receive both the investigational medication and the approved medication or standard of care at some point during the study and for investigators to gather additional clinical data.

Response.BaseQuestion: Why is there an open-label section after one year?
Response.Content: During an open-label component of a study, both the investigator and the participant in a research study know which study treatment the participant is receiving. The open-label period will allow for investigators to gather long-term data.

Response.BaseQuestion: Why do I have to have X-rays?
Response.Content: X-rays allow the study doctor to monitor your joints and determine if your condition is getting better or worse.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What kind of tests, therapies, and procedures will I have during this study?

Response.BaseQuestion: How do the tests compare to the standard tests for my condition?
Response.Content: As a participant in a clinical research study, you may need to have more frequent tests than would be required if you were being treated for your condition with standard of care medication. Frequent monitoring by your doctors helps to ensure your safety and allows doctors to learn more about your condition and how it is affected by the study medication.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is meant by standard of care treatment?
What kind of tests, therapies, and procedures will I have during this study?
Who will be working with me during the clinical study?
How is my safety checked in this study?
Why do I have to have X-rays?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the informed consent form?
Response.Content: Among other things, the informed consent form tells you what will happen during the study and explains the risks and any benefits you may experience if you choose to participate. Before choosing to be part of this study, you should read the entire informed consent form. You can also review the form with your loved ones or others to ensure you understand the commitment you are making by signing the consent form. The informed consent form or your study doctor will also explain other treatment options you have besides taking part in this study, as well as your right to stop taking part in the study at any time. If you wish to participate in the study, you will have to sign the informed consent form.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is informed consent?
What if I do not understand the Informed Consent form? Who can help me understand the Informed Consent form?
Do my family/friends need to know that I am participating in a clinical study?
Who can help me decide what is best for me?
Is it normal to feel uncertain about participating in a study?

Response.BaseQuestion: Who do I contact in an emergency?
Response.Content: Please call 911 if you have a health emergency. Let the doctors treating you know that you are participating in a clinical trial. The study doctor will also provide you with site contact information so that you or your other doctors can reach the site in an emergency.

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I withdraw from the study?
Response.Content: You can withdraw from the study at any time and for any reason.

Response.BaseQuestion: Are there risks and side effects of the study medication?
Response.Content: People taking the investigational medication have experienced some side effects. Any known risks will be discussed during the consent process, but there is always a possibility of unknown risks. Please see the informed consent form for a description of the side effects reported. Please also speak with the study doctor if you have any questions or concerns about the risks listed.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are the risks or side effects of this study treatment?
Could my rheumatoid arthritis get worse when receiving the study treatment?
What should I do if I experience side effects?/What happens if my RA gets worse during study treatment?

Response.BaseQuestion: Should I continue to see my regular doctor for other medical problems during this study?
Response.Content: Over the course of the clinical study, you should continue to be treated by your regular doctor. This doctor will be in charge of providing all non-study related care. It is important that you discuss any existing medical conditions with the study doctor or study staff so that they have a complete picture of your health, including any other medications or treatments that you may use. The investigational medication is not a substitute for any of your current treatments. It will not replace any of your medications; however, the use of some medications is restricted during the study. The study doctor will ask you about the medications you are currently taking and will tell you if any of them cannot be taken during the study. If your regular physician prescribes any other medications while you are in this study, you must first consult the study doctor prior to taking them. Tell the study doctor about any other medications you take after beginning the study, as the investigational medication may alter how well other medications work. In the event that a new medical problem arises over the course of the study, please inform both your regular doctor and the study doctor so that they can best coordinate your care.

Response.BaseQuestion: Who will have access to my medical records?/How will the study protect my confidential personal information?
Response.Content: The informed consent form describes who will have access to your medical records and how your confidential information will be used. Access to your medical records or other information about your participation in this study will be limited to protect your confidentiality.

Response.BaseQuestion: Contact information
Response.Content: If you are looking for contact information for Pfizer rheumatoid arthritis studies, please visit the listed link for the REFLECTIONS B538-02 study: http://www.pfizer.com/biosimilars/clinicaltrials/ReflectionsB53802/

RQ.BaseQuestion: How can I find clinical trials?
Introduction to program

Response.BaseQuestion: What is being tested in this study?/What is the purpose of this study?
Response.Content: The REFLECTIONS B538-02 study is looking at the safety and effectiveness of an investigational medication in patients with moderately to severely active rheumatoid arthritis.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are the types of clinical trials?

Response.BaseQuestion: Why might I be excluded from the study?
Response.Content: Participants who have previously taken HUMIRA, which is manufactured by AbbVie Inc. are not eligible for this study. There are additional criteria that may disqualify you from participating. You can discuss whether you are eligible to participate with a member of the study team. Sometimes patients who qualify and enroll in a study may later be removed from a study if the patient does not follow the study procedures or if the study doctor determines that it is not in the patient's best interest to continue in the study.

RQ.BaseQuestion: How long do I have to make my decision?
Who can participate in this study?

What will happen if I miss some study treatment doses or study appointments?
What will happen if I miss some appointments?

Response.BaseQuestion: What will the study treatment entail?
Response.Content: Participants in the REFLECTIONS B538-02 study will be divided into two study treatment groups. You will have an equal or 50 percent chance of being assigned to each of the groups. Each group will receive either the Pfizer investigational medication or adalimumab during the first treatment period. During the second treatment period, some patients receiving adalimumab during the first treatment period may be switched to receive the Pfizer investigational medication. In the third period, all patients will receive the Pfizer investigational medication.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are the types of clinical trials?
Is there a placebo in this study?
Why is the study treatment switched for participants during the study?
Why is there an open-label section after one year?
What is being tested in this study?/What is the purpose of this study?
Will the study treatment administration be painful?

Response.BaseQuestion: How long will the study last?
Response.Content: The REFLECTIONS B538-02 study will last approximately 82 weeks with a telephone call at 92 weeks. During the study period you will be asked to come to the study center approximately 19 times for study visits. If you are participating in REFLECTIONS B583-02, you will give yourself injections at home on the same day of the week every other week.

RQ.BaseQuestion: When will I find out about the trial results?
How many people will be enrolled in this study?
What happens after I stop or complete my study treatment in the study?
How many times will I have to visit the study doctor?

Response.BaseQuestion: How many times will I have to visit the study doctor?
Response.Content: If you participate in the REFLECTIONS B538-02 study, you will be asked to come to the study center approximately 19 times. The study doctor or study staff will provide or administer the study medication, carry out study procedures, and monitor your symptoms and overall health at the visits.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What will happen if I miss some study treatment doses or study appointments?

Response.BaseQuestion: Will there be lots of needles?/Will I have to have blood tests?
Response.Content: You will have blood tests as part of your study visits. The study medication will also be injected through a needle either by a member of the study staff at study visits or by you once you have been properly trained.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is adalimumab?
Response.Content: Adalimumab is a medication that is used to treat several inflammatory diseases and conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis. Adalimumab is marketed as HUMIRA by AbbVie Inc. In this study, the investigational medication is a potential biosimilar medication known as adalimumab-Pfizer. It is considered investigational in this study because it has not been approved for marketing. Biosimilar medications are highly similar versions of biologic drugs that are already approved for marketing. Biologic drugs are made from living cells.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are biosimilars?

What is the difference between biosimilar medications and generic medications?
What is HUMIRA?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is HUMIRA?
Response.Content: HUMIRA is a medication manufactured by AbbVie Inc. and approved by the Food and Drug Administration to treat several inflammatory diseases and conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are biosimilars?
What is the benefit of biosimilar medications to patients?

What is adalimumab?

Response.BaseQuestion: Will the study treatment administration be painful?
Response.Content: In the REFLECTIONS B538-02 study, all participants will receive their study medications through an injection under the skin with a needle, which might be a little painful.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Is it normal to feel uncertain about participating in a study?
What will the study treatment entail?

Response.BaseQuestion: Who do I contact for issues related to my medication administration at home?
Response.Content: For the REFLECTIONS B538-02 study, the study staff will provide you with contact information if you are having issues with taking the investigational medication at home, and will train a family member or other caregiver if you would prefer to have another person give the injections.
